Pathway.Name: Fragile X syndrome
Pathway.Comment: Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is a monogenetic disorder caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene and the most common form of inherited intellectual disability and autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Patients with FXS show a range of typical physical features such as macro-orchidism in males, a long and narrow face, large and protruding ears, and hyperextensible joints. Common comorbidities of FXS are neuropsychiatric disorders such as hyperactivity, depression and anxiety. The mutation of FMR1 in FXS disrupts production of the FMR1 gene product, the fragile mental retardation protein (FMRP). The main function of FMRP is to locally act as a translational repressor for target mRNAs and thereby regulate de novo protein synthesis and ultimately synaptic plasticity. FMRP, together with the mTOR pathway and the ERK pathway regulates expression of target mRNAsn mediated by stimulation of Group I metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluR) and thereby regulate α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptor (AMPAR) internalisation and thus long term depression (LTD). LTD is a form of synaptic plasticity which is involved in learning and memory. Lack of FMRP leads to exaggerated mGluR dependant LTD, which accounts for most of FXS pathogenesis.

DataNode.Comment: The short splice variant of Homer, Homer1a, competes with Homer 1 for the binding site on mGluR. In FXS mouse model, Homer1a has been shown to associate more with mGluR than Homer1, thereby it disrupts mGluR signalling and causes constitutive, agonist-independent activity of Group I mGluR.
Tyrosine-protein kinase Fyn (FYN) is a member of the Src family of tyrosine kinases which is involved in the regulation of brain function.
4-aminobutyrate aminotransferase (ABAT) is involved in GABA catabolism.
Activation of mTOR pathway is required for mGlur-LTD. mTOR activation is believed to sustain the increase in overall rate of mRNA translation at the synapse.
Calcineurin
Glutamate receptor-interacting protein 2 (GRIP2) also called AMPAR binding protein (ABP) interacts with GRIP1 to regulate AMPAR trafficking

postsynaptic density protein 95 (PSD-95 also known as SAP-90, encoded by the gene DLG4) is a PSD scaffolding protein, located at synapses, which is involved in the modulation of AMPAR ineternalization, stabilization of dendritic spines and synaptic strength. Translation of PSD-95 is negatively regulated by FMRP and miR-125a and positively regulated by mGluR activation. PSD-95 anchors synaptic proteins at the membrane and thus plays a cruicial role in synaptic plasticity and NMDAR-dependant LTP. In that sense, PSD-95 has a binary role, it serves as a structural scaffold which anchors AMPARs at the synapse. It also acts as a signalling scaffold required for LTD.

Sodium- and chloride-dependent GABA transporter 1 (SLC6A1 or GAT-1) has a function in GABA reuptake in the cortex, cerebellum and the whole forebrain. GAT-1 ends GABA action by removing GABA from the synaptic cleft and restoring it to presynaptic terminals.

Glutamate decarboxylase 1 (GAD1) encoded an enzyme (glutamic acid decarboxylase) that has a role in γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) synthesis. The enzyme catalyzes the production of GABA from L-glutamic acid.
Activation of ERK pathway is required for mGlur-LTD. ERK activation is thought to control the activation of specific mRNAs such as the LTD proteins.
aldehyde dehydrogenase 5 family member A1 (ALDHA1) and encodes encodes a mitochondrial NAD(+)-dependent succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenaseis that is involved in the catalysis of GABA.
γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system.

Exact subunits which make up PKA in thus pathway could not be found. PKA is made up of 2 regulary subunits and 2 catalytic subunits. Because no information on the composition of subunits in this case could have been found, subunits A have been used for regulatory and catalytic parts of PKA.

Gephyrin is involved in GABA receptor clustering in the cortex. Gephyrin is a neuronal assembly protein that anchors inhibitory neurotransmitter receptors, such as GABA receptors, to the postsynaptic cytoskeleton.
CAMK4 or CAMKIV
A-kinase anchor protein 5 (AKAP5) anchors protein kinase A (PKA) at the PSD by directly interacting with PSD-95. This interaction is important for NMDAR-dependant AMPAR endocytosis and LTD.
GABA rceeptor subunit γ
Rho GTPase activating protein 32 (ARHGAP32) is a neuron-associated GAP that may regulate dendritic spine morphology and strength through modulation of Rho GTPase activity.
GABA receptor subunit α

Tyrosine-protein phosphatase non-receptor type 5 (STEP) is involves to regulate AMPAR trafficking and negatively regulates AMPAR surface expression thereby contributing to mGluR-LTD. STEP promotes LTD by stimulating synaptic weakening by dephosphorylation of ERK1/2 and subunits of NDMA and AMPA receptors. STEP has been shown to promote NMDA internalization.
DICER, is an endonuclease, which cleaves double stranded RNA (dsRNA) into short single stranded RNA called miRNA and tehreby faciliates the activation of RISC
Protein Interacting with Kinase C 1 (PICK1)

N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA)-type glutamate receptors (NMDAR) are ionotropic receptors activated by glutamate. NMDAR activation allows Ca2+ influx leading to NMDAR-dependant LTP and LTD. NMDA receptors contribute to dendritic structure and thus, can have impact on neuronal firing.
GABA receptor subunit β
PP1 had 4 isomforms, however, in this pathway, only one (gene PPP1CA) has been used since literature did not specify which isoform is involved in this specific case.
CAMKII catalyzes the phosphorylation of AMPAR an

FMR1 gene product, called fragile mental retardation protein (FMRP) is a major regulator of mGluR-dependant protein synthesis and synaptic plasticity in hippocampus and cerebellum. It functions as a translational regulator of certain target mRNAs, is involved in denrite and axon developent as well as in learning and memory.

Microtubule-associated protein 1B (MAP1B) is involved in mcirotubule assembly and neurogenesis. MAP1b is involved in the regulation of the morphology of dendritic spines in glutamatergic synapses. Furthermore, MAP1b is a negative regulator of AMPAR surface expression thereby contributing to mGluR-LTD.
CYFIP1 interacts with FMRP and with translation initiation factor eIF4E

Activity-regulated cytoskeleton-associated protein (ARC) is a key regulator of synaptic plasticity. It is required for protein synthesis-dependent LTP and LTD as well as for the formation of long-term memory. ARC regulates synaptic plasticity by promoting endocytosis of AMPA receptors AMPAR and thus, LTD.
SOS, a guanine-associated echange factor (GEF), activates Ras by inducing the exchange of GTDP by GTP. This positively regulates Ras signalling.
NF1 functions as a guanine exchange factors (GEF), stimulating the conversion of GTP-bound RAS into GDP-bound RAS and tehreby negatively regulating the MEK-ERK-Mnk1 pathway.

calcium/calmodulin dependent protein kinase II alpha (CAMKIIα) is expressed at synapses where its translation is negatively regulated by FMRP. CAMKIIα is a key determinant for AMPAR internalization and thus LTD. The protein kinase mediates AMPAR internalization through phosphorylation of AMPAR subunits. CAMKIIα is involved in synaptic plasticity, neurotransmitter release and LTP.
Long homer variant

SAP90/PSD-95-associated protein 3 (SAPAP3) plays a role in the organization of synapses and neuronal cell signaling and is negatively regulated by FMRP. SAPAP3 is a postsynaptic scaffolding protein which is associated with PSD-95 and localized in dendrites. SAPAP3 plays an improtant role in maturation of synapses
Shank, an adapter protein in the PSD of excitatory synapses, is necessary for the structural and functional integrity of dendritic spines and synaptic junction.
Glutamate receptor ionotropic, NMDA 2B (GluN2B) is a subunit of the NMDAR receptor which is negatively regulated by FMRP.

CPT1A encodes the hepatic enzyme carnitine palmitoyltransferase 1A. The enzyme is responsible for fatty acid oxidation within the mitochondria, it connects carnitine to long-chain fatty acids thereby enabling the crossing of the fatty acid into the inner membrane of mitochondria. FMRP negatively regulates CPT1A and thus lipid metabolism.
Monocarboxylate transporter 1 (MCT1) is a proton coupled monocarboxylate transporter which function is to catalyse the rapid transport of many monocarboxylates across the plasma membrane.

Fatty aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH3A2) catalyzes the oxidation of long-chain aliphatic aldehydes to fatty acids. ALDH3A2 has shown to be essential for the detoxification of aldehydes generated by alcohol metabolism and lipid peroxidation.
ABCD3, a peroxisomal membrane protein, is involved in the transport of branched chain acyl-CoA into peroxisomes. ABCD3 is a fatty acid (FA) transporter protein.
Very-long-chain enoyl-CoA reductase (TECR) is responsible to catalyze the last of the four reactions of the long-chain fatty acids elongation cycle.

α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptors (AMPAR) are ionotropic glutamate transmembrane receptors that mediate the majority of fast excitatory transmission in the central nervous system (CNS).
AMPAR subunit GuA1
AMPAR subunit GluA2
Endophoilin 2
Dynamin is a large GTPase modulating release of endosomes from the membrane by pinching off and fissioning the membrane.
Phosphorylated 4E-BP cannot bind to eIF4E anymore, this means that its inhibitory effect on translation is repressed
Methyl-CpG-binding protein 2 (MECP2) is a nuclear protein that is capable of binding to methylated DNA. It is essential for nerve cell functionality.
Ephrin type-A receptor 4 (EPHA4) is a receptor tyrosine kinase binding tp ephrin ligands. EPHA4 is has a function in the development of the nervous system.
NMDA receptor subunit 2 A
Cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2A (CDKC2A)
Endopilin 3

Exact subunits which make up PKA in thus pathway could not be found. PKA is made up of 2 regulary subunits and 2 catalytic subunits. Because no information on the composition of subunits in this case could have been found, subunits A have been used for regulatory and catalytic parts of PKA.

Amyloid-beta precursor protein (APP), large membrane-spanning glycoprotein, is implicated in neurogenesis and synapse formation. It is mainly expressed in synapses. APP is suspected to contribute to altered mGluR-LTD.
Type your comment here
N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA)-type glutamate receptors (NMDAR) are ionotropic receptors activated by glutamate. NMDAR activation allows Ca2+ influx leading to NMDAR-dependant LTP and LTD
Clathrin mediates the endocytosis of NMDAR by binding to AP-2
N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA)-type glutamate receptors (NMDAR) are ionotropic receptors activated by glutamate. NMDAR activation allows Ca2+ influx leading to NMDAR-dependant LTP and LTD
PTEN is enhanced by FMRP and negatively regulates GABA A receptor subunits, this way PTEN has a protective role in reducing GABA A deficiency-indiced incidence of seizures
PTEN is enhanced by FMRP and negatively regulates GABA A receptor subunits, this way PTEN has a protective role in reducing GABA A deficiency-indiced incidence of seizures
Also referred to as VHR, a ERK specific phosphatase
Eukarytic translation elongation factor (EF1α)
Potassium/sodium hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channel 1 (HCN1)
Protein Kinase C
mGluR activation leads to activation of the PLC pathway which induces release of Ca2+ and PKC. PKC will phohsphorylate and activate RAF1 and tehereby activate RAF1 and thus the ERK pathway
RAP1 is phsohprylated and activated by PKA and in turn stimulates the activation of B-Raf, thus leading to the activation of the ERK pathway

Epidermal growth factor receptor pathway substrate 8-related protein 1 (EPS8L1) is an FMRP target and important for teh remodelling of actin in response to EGF stimulation. EPS8L1 gene product EPS8 is needed for normal spine morphology, synaptic plasticity, and memory formation. EPS8 has been shown to be downregulated in autism, since it's a binding partner of FMRP, it is likely that it is also downregulated in FXS.
Shank, an adapter protein in the PSD of excitatory synapses, is necessary for the structural and functional integrity of dendritic spines and synaptic junction.

Tyrosine-protein phosphatase non-receptor type 5 (STEP) is involves to regulate AMPAR trafficking and negatively regulates AMPAR surface expression thereby contributing to mGluR-LTD. STEP promotes LTD by stimulating synaptic weakening by dephosphorylation of ERK1/2 and subunits of NDMA and AMPA receptors. STEP has been shown to promote NMDA internalization.

Microtubule-associated protein 1B (MAP1B) is involved in mcirotubule assembly and neurogenesis. MAP1b is involved in the regulation of the morphology of dendritic spines in glutamatergic synapses. Furthermore, MAP1b is a negative regulator of AMPAR surface expression thereby contributing to mGluR-LTD.

Tyrosine-protein phosphatase non-receptor type 5 (STEP) is involves to regulate AMPAR trafficking and negatively regulates AMPAR surface expression thereby contributing to mGluR-LTD. STEP promotes LTD by stimulating synaptic weakening by dephosphorylation of ERK1/2 and subunits of NDMA and AMPA receptors. STEP has been shown to promote NMDA internalization.
Also referred to as VHR, a ERK specific phosphatase

Interaction.Comment: Shank, a major scaffolding protein in the PSD, binds to the EVH1 domain of the Homer protein, together they form a mesh-like structure and are involved the recruitment of proteins at the synapse and are required for structural integrity of dendritic spines.

mGluR mediated mobilization of endocannabinoids activates cannabinoid receptor 1(CNR1) on the presynaptic cholecystokinin interneuron terminal located in the hippocampus. This in turn suppresses GABA release.

STEP catalyses the dephosphorylation of NMDA receptor 2B (NR2B or GRIN2B) at the site Y1472. As a consequence, AP-2 can associate with NMDA and mediate clathrin-dependant endocytosis of NMDAR and thus promote NMDA-mediated LTD.
The MAP3K trier transmits the signal downstream through phosphorylation and activation of the MAPKKs (Mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase) MEK 1 and MEK 2 (MEK 1/2)
mGluR activation leads to activation of the PLC IP3 pathway to release Ca2+ and activate PKC alpha which phohphorylates AMPAR subunit GluA2 at Ser880 and induces endocytosis of AMPAR
Scr is activated through mGluR and can activate the ERK pathway through RAF1
CAMKIV phosphorylates CREB and thereby regulates the trascription of FMRP.

Fyn catalyses the phosphorylation of NMDA receptor 2B at the site Y1472. Phosphorylation of the NMDA receptor will result in dissociation from AP-2 and thus inhibit clathrin-mediated endocytosis and thus LTD.
mGluR activation leads to activation of the PLC pathway which induces release of Ca2+ and PKC. PKC will phohsphorylate and activate RAF1 and tehereby activate RAF1 and thus the ERK pathway
AP2 binds to tyrosine-based internalization motif (YELK) which contains the Y1472 site which results in clathrin mediated endocytosis of NR2B (GRIN2B)
Activated, GTP bound Ras, recruits RAF1, BRAF and ARAF, the MAP3K (MAP kinase kinase kinase) trier of the cascade, and stimulates their protein kinase activity
CaMKII interacts with with AMPAR subunit GluA2 and catalyzes the phosphorylation of AMPAR, promoting receptor insertion into the synaptic membrane and LTP.
MEK 1/2 subsequently phosphorylate and activate ERK 1 and 2 (ERK1/2) at their Thr and Tyr residues within the Thr-Glu-Tyr domain of the activation loop
PI3K catalyzes the phosphorylation of PIP2 into PIP3
AMPAR receptors can be recycled and re-inserted into the membrane
PSD-95 (postsynaptic density protein 95) is is recruited and interacts with the NR2 subuni of the NMDA receptor upon NDMAR activation.
Phosphorylated CREB initiates CREB-dependant transcription of the FMR1 gene, thereby CREB upregulates FMRP (FMR1 gene product)
Glutamate Receptor Interacting Protein (GRIP) interacts with AMPAR binding protein (ABP or GRIP2) to anchor AMPARs at synaptic and intracelluar membranes, thereby inhibiting AMPAR internalization.
PIP3 recruits PDK1 and Akt to the membrane

ARC interacts with dynamin and isoforms of endophilin (isoform 2 and 3 only) to stimulate AMPAR internalization and thus negatively regulate AMPAR surface expression. Rapid mGluR-mediated synthesis of ARC is required for to maintain decrease in surafce AMPAR and thereby maintaining LTD.
Calcineurin/Dynamin 1 complex stimulates clathrin-mediated endocytosis of AMPAR
ARC, dynamin and endophilin bind in an cooperative assembly that stimulates AMPAR endocytosis.
The MAP3K trier transmits the signal downstream through phosphorylation and activation of the MAPKKs (Mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase) MEK 1 and MEK 2 (MEK 1/2)
Modest activation of NMDAR leads to repeated occurance of a small Ca2+ influx which leads to the activation of NMDA dependant protein phosphatases, protein phosphatase 1 and Calcineurin
In turn, activated ERK 1/2 phosphorylates MAPKAPK (MAP Kinase Activated Protein Kinase) components such as MNK1
Maximal influx of Ca2+ through strong activation NMDAR activates PICK1 (Protein Interacting with C Kinase - 1)
Elevated cAMP levels lead to the activation of cAMP dependant protein kinase (PKA)
Activation of TrkB recruits and activates Shc and adaptor protein Gbr2. PI3K is activated via Gbr2 through Gab1.
Activation of PLC (phospholipase C) through mGluR or TrkB leads to hydrolysis of membrane bound PIP2 (phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate) to generate IP3 and DAG.
The MAP3K trier transmits the signal downstream through phosphorylation and activation of the MAPKKs (Mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase) MEK 1 and MEK 2 (MEK 1/2)
PDK1 phosphorylates and activates Akt
Generation of IP3 from PIP2 via PLC lead to the release of intracellular Ca2+. This leads to the activation CaM (Ca2+-calmodulin) dependant pathways
Activation adn mobilization of endocannabinoids through mGluR activation negatively regulates GABA release from the synapse.
Activated TrkB (tyrosine kinase B) recruits and activates PLC, this triggers PLC intracellular cascades
4E binding protein (4E-BP) associates with eIF4E, thereby inhibits the assembly of the eIF4F complex and represses translation

AMPAR internaliztion/endocytosis is clathrin mediated and activated through NMDAR stimulation. Local protein synthesis of postsynaptic, dendritic localized mRNAs, regulated through mGluR receptor activation and FMRP regulation, results in internalization of AMPAR, which is a key step in mGluR-mediated long term depression (LTD).
Activation of PI3K through activated Ras mediated by the TrkB signalling pathway
Group I mGluR activation stimulates eCB signalling and leads to actovation and mobilization of endocannabinoids which inhibit the release of GABA.
Activated PSD-95 directly interacts with synaptic ras GTPase-activating protein (SynGAP)
Homer mediates the association between type I mGluR to PIKE-L
PI3K is activated via Gbr2 through Gab1 by a TrkB dependant manner.
STEP catalyzes the dephosphorylation of AMPAR subunit GluA2 in order to maintain increased AMPAR endocytosis rate.
Group I mGluRs are coupled to PLC (Phospholipase C) through Gαq. Activation of mGluR by glutamate leads to activation of PLC which triggers the PLC signalling pathway
PP1 and Calcineurin dephospharylate AMPAR which stimulates AMPAR internalization and thus, LTD.
Activated, GTP bound Ras, recruits RAF1, BRAF and ARAF, the MAP3K (MAP kinase kinase kinase) trier of the cascade, and stimulates their protein kinase activity
Adaptor protein 2 (AP2) interacts with AMPAR and mediates recruitment of clathrin and clathrin-mediated endocytosis of AMPAR.

PKCα is recruited by PICK1 and binds to the PDZ domain of PICK1 and subsequently phosphorylates GluR2 subunit of AMPAR. Phosphorylation of GluR2 by PKCα is necessary for PICK1 binding, since GRIP and PICK1 have the same binding site on the domain and GRIP dissociation is necessary for PICK1 binding and consequent endocytosis of AMPAR

Activation of TrkB and thus autophosphorylation of its Try515 site recruits and phosphorylates Shc. Subsequently, Shc interacts with the adapotor protein Grb2 which recruits and activates SOS (a GEF).
Calcineurin-dynamin 1 interaction is essential from AMPA clathrin-mediated receptor endocytosis. The formation of the calcineurin-dynamin 1 complex is dependent on Ca2+ influx.
Activated cAMP-dependant protein kinase (PKA) phosphorylates and activates the transcription factor cAMP response element-binding protein (CREB) at Ser133
MAP1b interacts with GRIP and sequesters GRIP and associated AMPAR from the synaptic surface
PICK1 recruits PKCα which phophorylates AMPAR subunit GluA2 at Ser880 and thereby dissociates GRIP from AMPAR allowing PICK1 to bind to the GluA2. PICK1/GluA2 interaction induces AMPAR endocytosis.
PIKE-L (Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase enhancer) binds to PI3K and stimulates PI3K's kinase activity
CaM phosphorylates CAMIV
Clathrin mediates AMPAR endocytosis by binding to AP-2 complex. AP-2 complex is bound to AMPAR and recruits clathrin to the receptor to form a clathrin-coated vesicle containg AMPAR.
SynGAP is a negtaive regulator of ras and thus also a negative regulator of the ERK1/2 cascade, thereby having a role in neuronal development and plasticity
Activated mTORC1 phophorylates PP2A, thereby inhibiting PP2A's phopsphatase activity
Ribosomal protein S6 kinase 1 (S6K1) phosphorylates FMRP, allowing phosphorylated FMRP to bind to stalling ribosomes and thereby repress translation
FMRP represses the action PI3K and thereby negatively regulates the mTOR pathway
Protein phasphatase 2 (PP2) dephosphorylates FMRP. Unphosphorylated FMRP is associated with actively translating polyribosomes.
Activation of MNK1 phosphorylates eIF4E of the eIF4E-CYFIP1-FMRP inhibitory complex. The phosphorylation of eIF4E releases the CYFIP1-FMRP complex from the mRNA and enables translation
Phosphorylation of the 4E-BP by mTORC1 leads to inactivation of 4E-BP and thus induces translation of proteins

TSC2 acts as GAD (GTPase activating protein) towards RHEB, converting it from the active GTP-bound state to the inactive GDP-bound state. This activity is inhibited by phosphorylation of TSC2 through AKT. As a consequence, the conversion of GTP bound RHEB to GDP bound RHEB is inhibited.
Through inhibition of the TSC complex and thus conversion of RHEB-GTP to RHEB-GDP, there is accumulation of RHEB-GTP which stimulates and activates mTORC1.
Activated, GTP bound Ras, recruits RAF1, BRAF and ARAF, the MAP3K (MAP kinase kinase kinase) trier of the cascade, and stimulates their protein kinase activity
FMRP represses the action PIKE and thereby negatively regulates the mTOR pathway
mTORC1 phosphorylates and activates S6K1 which induces its kinase activity
mGluR is bound to HOMER which mediates activation of the PI3K-Akt-mTOR pathway
AKT directly phosphorylates TSC2 on Ser939, Ser981 and Thr1462. This leads to inactivation of TSC2, which inhibits its GAP (GTPase-accelerating protein) activity
PTEN catalyzes the conversion of PIP3 to PIP2

GraphicalLine.Comment: Loss of FMRP may be linked to impaired NMDAR LTP
FXS: disrupted scaffolding of mGluR with Homer, leads to abnormal mGluR activity
Hypofunction in the hippocampal dentate gyrus may partly contribute to cognitive impairments in FXS.
In FMR1 KO, AKT activation is increased
Elevated activity of ERK in FMR1 KO mouse model
Reduced insertion of AMPAR into the synaptic membrane leads to impaired synaptic plasticity in FXS and contributes to enhanced mGluR-LTD in FXS

Exaggerated mGluR signalling in FXS results in overactivation of TrkB signalling as a compensatory mechanism in order to physically alter the shape of dendrites to prepare in advance for low postsynaptic activity. Activation of TrkB receptors by BDNF initiates intracellular cascades that locally initate the ramification of dendrites and formation of spines.
Loss of FMRP: increase in synthesis of CAMKIIα which hyperphosphorylates Homer and thus leads to Homer dissocation from mGluR
FMRP loss: enhaced phosphorylation of 4E-BP leading to enhanced inhibition of 4E-BP binding to the eIF4F complex. This leads to elevated levels of eIF4F complex.

FMRP negatively regulates the mTOR pathway through inhibition of PIKE and PI3K. In FXS, FMRP is lost, this leads to suppression of the negative feedback given to the mTOR pathway and leads to upregulation of PIKE and PI3K. Altogether, the mTOR signalling pathway is upregulated.
Upregulation of PI3K leads to overactivation of mTOR.
Increased activation of PIKE (PIKE is being de-repressed) which promotes enhanced activation of PI3K
Enhanced Group I mGluR activity has been reported in FMR1 KO animal models. Overactivation of GluR1/5 mediate most symptomes of FXS.
FXS symptoms linked with Group I mGluR overactivation are illustrated in the above red box
Enhanced cap-mediated translation initiation in FXS leading to excessive protein synthesis.

Loss of FMRP, leads to exaggerated mGluR-LTD which may lead to slowed net synaptic maturation, thereby contributing to developmental delay, dysmorphogenesis of dendritic spines and loss of motor coordination, which are the main features of FXS. Increased mGluR-LTD leads to slow synaptic maturation, developmental delay, cognitive impairment, epilepsy, increased density of of long thin dendritic spines and loss of motor coordination.
Loss of FMRP enhances coupling between mGluR and endocannabinoid synthesis and release
Loss of FMRP has as a consequence, reduced expression of GABA A receptors. GABA A receptor deficiency leads to the occurence of epileptic seizure in FXS.

Loss of FMRP: Increased synthesis of SLC16A1 (a monocarboxylate transporter) may favor hepatic transport of KB (terminal breakdown product of mitochondrial β oxidation). This may contribute to the elevation of the circulating levels of KB acetone and acetoacetate in FMR1 KO mouse.
Overexpression of the transporters ABCD3 and ALDH3A2 may be responsible for increased peroxisomal β oxidation of lipids
Overexpression of the transporters ABCD3 and ALDH3A2 may be responsible for increased peroxisomal β oxidation of lipids
In FMR! KO mouse, PTEN activity is decreased
Increased activation of mTOR due to upregulation of PIKE and PI3K (negative feedback from experted on PIKE and PI3K by FMRP is abolished)
FMRP loss: abnormal increase in microtubule stability leading to impaied synaptic maturation, abnormalities in spine maturation and synapse formation and abnormal mGluR-LTD.
Loss of FMRP: Increased phosphorylation of PP2A
Loss of FMRP: Invcreased phosphrylation of S6K1
FMRP loss and thus upregulation of de novo Shank synthesis leads to enlargment of dendritic spines and contributes to spine dysmorphogenesis observed in FXS.

Loss of FMRP leads to upregulation of APP and its metabolites, which is linked to impaired synaptic function, neuronal overgrowth and increase in brain volume (which can be associated with macrocephaly as a symptome of FXS). APP dysregulation is also linked to hyperactivity.
ARC

STEP promotes LTD by stimulating synaptic weakening by dephosphorylation of ERK1/2 (inactivation of ERK1/2) and subunits of NDMA and AMPA receptors. Thus, loss of FMRP leads to overactivation of STEP protein synthesis and increase in LTD.
VHR tempers and shortens ERK activation through its phosphatase activity. Loss of FMRP upregulates phosphatase activity of VHR
Decreased expression of GABA A-γ is associated with audiogenic seizures, hyperactivity and prepulse inhibition

Label.Comment: Loss of FMRP in the anterior cingulate cortex leads to fear memory impairment and synaptic plasticity alterations. This may be responsible for certain types of mental disorders in FXS.
Dysregulation in cAMP is believed to contribute to the neuropathophysiology of FXS
Related FXS phenotypes: Anxiety, autism spectrum disorders, seizures

Target mRNA regulated are involved in GABA metabolism, GABA membrane transportes and GABA scaffolding protein. FMRP regulates the expression of GABA receptor subunits. GABAergic signalling is essential for the regulation of neuronal maturation and migration and for neuronal circuit formation.

FXS patients show metabolic anomalies. FXS patients have shown to have significant low levels of plasma cholesterol levels, reduced total choesterol, LDL and HDL. Furthermore, FMR1 Ko models have shown reduced circulating glucose, insulin levels and increased fatty acid levels in the circuitry system.
The TSC1 complex is a negative regulator of mTORC1, when phosphorylated, its inhibitory activity is repressed

Upon activation of Group I mGluR, there is rapid translation of proteins which mediate postsynaptic internalization of AMPAR eventually leading to mGluR-dependant LTD. As a consequence, LTD lowers the postsynaptic receptor densisty, thereby allowing the formation of new connection via LTP. LTD mechanisms are essential for activity-guided synapse elimination. AN important feature of mGluR-LTD is that it is irreversible in contrast to NMDAR-LTD.
Exaggerated mGluR-LTD in CA1 neurons leads to cognitive impairment and developmental delay.
mGluR is expressed in the enteric innervation of the ileum, overactivation of mGluR may affect intesinal mobility, since fragile x patients often complain about loose bowels.
LTD proteins refers to proteins in dendrites that induce LTD at locally active synapses

Hypothesis 1: Repression of translation via FMRP is mediated through the RNA interference (RNAi) pathway. FMRP associates with Argonaute 2 and Dicer, components of the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC), and to specific miRNAs. The KH domains of teh FMRP protein help the miRNA associate on their target mRNA, thus miRNA-RISC comple

AMPA internalization is either mediated via te NMDAR pathway or through rapid translation of 'LTD proteins' mediated by mGluR activation. The proteins involved in AMPAR endocytosis and thus LTD, are referred to as 'LTD proteins'. AMPAR endocytosis is triggered by de novo synthesis of LTD proteins.
FMRP contols hepatic/lipid metabolism of key enzymes and transporters through direct translational regulation or through compensatory/adaptive mechanisms.
Group I metabotrobic glutamate receptors 1 and 5 are synaptic receptors involved in synaptic plasticity
mTORC1 complex directly regulates protein synthesis in mammals

Hypothesis 2: FMRP inhibits translation of target mRNA through binding to the coding sequence that are associated with actively translating ribosomes, thereby acting as a steric block for ribosome elongation and thus, translation.

Hypothesis 3: FMRP inhibits cap-dependant translation. Cap-dependent translation requires eIF4F complex (comosed of eIFG-eIF4F-eIF4E) for translational initiation and are inhibited when 4E-binding proteins (4E-BP) interfer with the complex. FMRP inhibits this type of translation by recruiting and binding cytoplasmic FMRP-interacting protein (CYFIP1) to target mRNAs and subsequently associates with eIF4E, thereby forming a FMRP/CYFIP1/eIF4E complex, blocking the recruitment of the translation initation machinery.
AMPAR exosytosis mediates the increase in synaptic strength during LTP.
NMDA-LTD is revesible and induced upon the activation of NMDA receptors. NMDAR-LTD is essential for working and space memory.
Exaggerated LTD in the cerebellar cortex leads to loss of motor coordination.

Fear memory formation and LTP are dependant on mGluR5. FMR1 KO mouse show abnormal contextual and conditional fear responses. mGluR-LTP and NMDA-LTP have been correlated with anxiety-like behaviors in FXS.
mGluR-dependant LTP in the corticostriatal synapse is linked to obsessive-compulsive behaviours in FXS.
Heightened behavioral responses to sensory stimuli
mGluR overactivation in c-fiber innervation of the skin leads to heightened sensitivity to tactile irritation.
mGluR overactivation in the suprachiasmatic nucleus has shown to disrupt circadian rythm in Drosophila.
Related FXS phenotype: Seizures, cognitive dysfunction, sensory hypersensitivity
Relatred FXS phenotypes: Frontostriatal dysfunction, involved in hyperactivity disorder and repetitive behaviour observed in FXS phenotype
Related FXS phenotypes: Seizures, cogniitve impairment
Related FXS phenotypes: Seizures, cognitive impairment, circuit hyperplasticity
NMDA-LTD is revesible and induced upon the activation of NMDA receptors. NMDAR-LTD is essential for working and space memory. mGluR facilitates NMDAR-LTP.

Shape.Comment: With FMRP loss, there is loss of the translational repression activity of FMRP. This leads to overexpression of target mRNAs.
With FMRP loss, there is loss of the translational repression activity of FMRP. This leads to overexpression of target mRNAs.
With FMRP loss, there is loss of the enhances protein expression by FMRP to GABAergic system components
